Another Bain / LOC / Mutual Film Co. photo identifies the man at right as "Rodriquez."
Pancho Villa and Rodriquez, hats in hand:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5169602076/in/photostream/#]

PANCHO VILLA'S ARRANGEMENT WITH THE MUTUAL FILM COMPANY:

"In January 1914, Pancho Villa became Hollywood's first Mexican superstar when he signed an exclusive contract with the Mutual Film Corporation. In return for $25,000, he agreed to keep other film companies from his battlefield, to fight in daylight whenever possible, and to reconstruct battles if the footage needed reshooting. 

"Now the subject of an HBO film starring Antonio Banderas (And Starring Pancho Villa as Himself), Villa is one of the main protagonists in Margarita de Orellana's vivid account of the American movie industry's fascination with the events of the Mexican Revolution. 

"Through memoir accounts, newspaper reports, and analysis of the films themselves, "Filming Pancho" reveals much about how Mexico was constructed in the American imagination and how the film images reinforced and justified American expansionism and racial and social prejudices."

--From a description, on Amazon, of a documentary movie of Hollywood's treatment of the Mexican Revolution. (The DVD is available for purchase from various Amazon vendors.)

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content:
Esta foto pudiera corresponder al 25 de noviembre de 1913  (por la secuencia 2961-2), después de la Batalla de Tierra Blanca.  Se aprecia el botín de guerra en el fondo hay otras fotos del mismo acto, en el mismo sitio, que hacen juego con ésta. El día 3 de enero de 1914 Villa firmó su contrato con la Mutual para que esta compañía filmara sus batallas.
La Batalla de Ojinaga se llevó a cabo el dia 10 de enero.  En todo caso la foto correspondería a esta fecha. Y el que lo acompaña no es un director holiwoodense, se trata del general Pánfilo Natera
Dr. Roberto Duarte

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content:
Maybe you wonder what Panfilo Natera has to do in this picture taken in the northern border of the State of Chihuahua, being a revolutionary general that  used to fight in the central State of Zacatecas?
Well, by December 20 Villa summoned main generals in Chihuahua to organize the strategy to attack Ojinaga.  Natera was also present (because he was trying to confer Carranza in Sonora, but American authorities declined to let him pass through El Paso).  Villa proposed Toribio Ortega, or as a courtesy, Pánfilo Natera to take command of the army.  The generals chose Natera.  The column departed from Chihuahua on December 22, 1913.  On January 2, 1914 villistas were on sight to Ojinaga, on January 4ht town was attacked without success.  Then Villa took command of the army.  His plan was a nocturnal raid: Rosalío Hernandes by the south; Maclovio Herrera and Trinidad Rodríguez  by east; by the West Toribio Ortega. On January 11th at sunset, the raids went simultaneously.   The federals (huertistas), leaving fire arms, crossed Rio Bravo and surrendered to American authorities. Villa and his revolutionary army stayed in Ojinaga three or four days, then they returned to Chihuahua.  (Pedro Salmerón, La División Del Norte).  So this picture (and 4th, 5th above [Mutual]) were taken among those days.
Dr. Roberto Duarte
